natural problem: The lengths of two sides of a triangle are 33 units and 42 units. The third side also has an integral length. What is the least possible number of units in the perimeter of the triangle?
natural solution: The sum of the smaller two sides must exceed the greatest side, so if $x$ is the missing side then $x+33>42\implies x>9$. The smallest integer greater than 9 is 10, so the least perimeter is $10+33+42=\boxed{85}$ units.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 33"
and h1 : "b = 42"
and h2 : "c \<in> \<int>"
and h3 : "a + b > c"
and h4 : "a + c > b"
and h5 : "b + c > a"
shows  "a + b + c \<ge> 85"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The lengths of two sides of a triangle are 33 units and 42 units. The third side also has an integral length. What is the least possible number of units in the perimeter of the triangle? The final Answer is 85
 ### Proof
 The sum of the smaller two sides must exceed the greatest side, so if $x$ is the missing side then $x+33>42\implies x>9$. The smallest integer greater than 9 is 10, so the least perimeter is $10+33+42=\boxed{85}$ units.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 33"
and h1 : "b = 42"
and h2 : "c \<in> \<int>"
and h3 : "a + b > c"
and h4 : "a + c > b"
and h5 : "b + c > a"
shows  "a + b + c \<ge> 85"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given that $a=33$, $b=42$, and $c$ is an integer such that $a+b>c$, $a+c>b$, and $b+c>a$, find the smallest possible value of $a+b+c$. The answer is 85 or larger.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 33"
and h1 : "b = 42"
and h2 : "triangle a b c"
shows  "c \<ge> 10" and "a + b + c \<ge> 85"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The lengths of two sides of a triangle are 33 units and 42 units. The third side also has an integral length. What is the least possible number of units in the perimeter of the triangle? The final Answer is 85
 ### Proof
 The sum of the smaller two sides must exceed the greatest side, so if $x$ is the missing side then $x+33>42\implies x>9$. The smallest integer greater than 9 is 10, so the least perimeter is $10+33+42=\boxed{85}$ units.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 33"
and h1 : "b = 42"
and h2 : "triangle a b c"
shows  "c \<ge> 10" and "a + b + c \<ge> 85"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given a triangle with sides of length $33$ and $42$, what is the minimum possible value for the length of the third side, and what is the minimum possible sum of the side lengths? The final answers are $c \geq 10$ and $a + b + c \geq 85$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 33"
and h1 : "b = 42"
and h2 : "c \<ge> abs(a - b) + 1"
and h3 : "c \<le> a + b - 1"
and h4 : "triangle_inequality a b c"
shows  "least_perimeter: a + b + c = 85"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The lengths of two sides of a triangle are 33 units and 42 units. The third side also has an integral length. What is the least possible number of units in the perimeter of the triangle? The final Answer is 85
 ### Proof
 The sum of the smaller two sides must exceed the greatest side, so if $x$ is the missing side then $x+33>42\implies x>9$. The smallest integer greater than 9 is 10, so the least perimeter is $10+33+42=\boxed{85}$ units.
 *)

fixes a b c :: nat

and h1 : "b = 42"
and h2 : "c \<ge> abs(a - b) + 1"
and h3 : "c \<le> a + b - 1"
and h4 : "triangle_inequality a b c"
shows  "least_perimeter: a + b + c = 85"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given that $a = 33$, $b = 42$, and $c$ satisfies the triangle inequality, find the smallest possible value of $c$ such that $a + b + c = 85$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 33"
and h1 : "b = 42"
and h2 : "c \<ge> abs(a - b) + 1"
and h3 : "c \<le> a + b - 1"
and h4 : "c = (LEAST x. x \<ge> abs(a - b) + 1 \<and> x \<le> a + b - 1)"
shows  "a + b + c = 85"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The lengths of two sides of a triangle are 33 units and 42 units. The third side also has an integral length. What is the least possible number of units in the perimeter of the triangle? The final Answer is 85

 *)

fixes a b c :: nat

and h2 : "c \<ge> abs(a - b) + 1"
and h3 : "c \<le> a + b - 1"
and h4 : "c = (LEAST x. x \<ge> abs(a - b) + 1 \<and> x \<le> a + b - 1)"
shows  "a + b + c = 85"

a_3.informal problem: Given that $a = 33$ and $b = 42$, find the smallest possible value of $c$ such that $c \ge |a - b| + 1$ and $c \le a + b - 1$. What is the sum of $a$, $b$, and $c$? The final answer is 85.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 33"
and h1 : "b = 42"
and h2 : "triangle a b c"
and h3 : "c \<in> {n. \<forall> k \<in> {1..n}. k dvd n}"
shows  "a + b + c = 85"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The lengths of two sides of a triangle are 33 units and 42 units. The third side also has an integral length. What is the least possible number of units in the perimeter of the triangle? The final Answer is 85

 *)

fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 33"
and h1 : "b = 42"
and h2 : "triangle a b c"
and h3 : "c \<in> {n. \<forall> k \<in> {1..n}. k dvd n}"
shows  "a + b + c = 85"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given a triangle with sides of length $a=33$, $b=42$, and $c$. If $c$ is a number such that every integer from $1$ to $c$ divides $c$, what is the sum of $a$, $b$, and $c$? The final answer is $85$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 33"
and h1 : "b = 42"
and h2 : "c \<in> {n. n \<in> {1..(a + b - 1)} \<and> a + b > n \<and> a + n > b \<and> b + n > a}"
shows  "least_perimeter :: nat = (GREATEST p. \<exists> c. p = a + b + c \<and> c \<in> h2)" and "least_perimeter = 85"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The lengths of two sides of a triangle are 33 units and 42 units. The third side also has an integral length. What is the least possible number of units in the perimeter of the triangle? The final Answer is 85
 ### Proof
 The sum of the smaller two sides must exceed the greatest side, so if $x$ is the missing side then $x+33>42\implies x>9$. The smallest integer greater than 9 is 10, so the least perimeter is $10+33+42=\boxed{85}$ units.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 33"
and h1 : "b = 42"
and h2 : "c \<in> {n. n \<in> {1..(a + b - 1)} \<and> a + b > n \<and> a + n > b \<and> b + n > a}"
shows  "least_perimeter :: nat = (GREATEST p. \<exists> c. p = a + b + c \<and> c \<in> h2)" and "least_perimeter = 85"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: A triangle has sides with lengths 33 and 42. Find the smallest possible integer value for the length of the third side, such that the triangle inequality holds (i.e., the sum of any two sides is greater than the third side). Calculate the least perimeter of such a triangle. The final answer is 85.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 33"
and h1 : "b = 42"
and h2 : "c = (LEAST c. c \<ge> 1 \<and> c \<in> \<int> \<and> a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a)"
shows  "a + b + c = 85"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The lengths of two sides of a triangle are 33 units and 42 units. The third side also has an integral length. What is the least possible number of units in the perimeter of the triangle? The final Answer is 85

 The sum of the smaller two sides must exceed the greatest side, so if $x$ is the missing side then $x+33>42\implies x>9$. The smallest integer greater than 9 is 10, so the least perimeter is $10+33+42=\boxed{85}$ units.
 *)

fixes a b c :: real

shows  "a + b + c = 85"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the smallest integer value of $c$ such that $a = 33$, $b = 42$, and $a, b, c$ form the sides of a triangle. What is the sum of $a, b,$ and $c$? The final answer is $85$.
